questions.text: Which cells are not present in the layer marked as D? (AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Langerhans cells

 

  • The layer marked as D is stratum basale.
  • Langerhan's cells are not present in stratum basale.
  • Langerhan's cells are predominantly present in stratum spinosum.
  • Keratinocytes, Merkel cells & Melanocytes are all seen in Stratum Basale.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Keratinocytes: Keratinocytes are the most prevalent cells in the epidermis and are definitely found in the stratum basale. They are responsible for the production of keratin, a key structural protein in the skin.

 

Option B. Merkel cells: Merkel cells are mechanoreceptor cells that are present in the basal layer of the epidermis. They are involved in the sensation of light touch.

 

Option C. Melanocytes: Melanocytes are also present in the stratum basale. These cells produce melanin, the pigment that gives skin its color and provides protection against UV radiation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

 

Ref - Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition: Volume 1 Chapter 2, Page no 2.4

choices.text: Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin-mediated? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Septicemia

 

Septicemia (also known as bloodstream infection) caused by Staphylococcus aureus is not mediated by toxins but by the direct invasion of the bloodstream by the bacterial organisms. This leads to the systemic immune response, triggering widespread inflammation, resulting in the clinical manifestations of sepsis such as fever, hypotension, and organ dysfunction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Food poisoning: Food poisoning caused by Staphylococcus aureus is mediated by enterotoxins, which are pre-formed toxins in contaminated food. Symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea occur rapidly after ingestion due to these toxins.

 

Option B. Toxic shock syndrome: Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is a toxin-mediated condition caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), produced by Staphylococcus aureus. This exotoxin leads to severe systemic symptoms like fever, rash, hypotension, and multiorgan dysfunction.

 

Option D. Staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome (SSSS): SSSS is mediated by the exfoliative toxin, which causes separation of the epidermis, leading to widespread blistering and skin peeling, mimicking a burn.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Septicemia caused by Staphylococcus aureus is an infection due to bacterial invasion and is not toxin-mediated, whereas conditions like food poisoning, toxic shock syndrome, and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome are caused by staphylococcal toxins.

questions.text: Which of the following is an anti-apoptotic factor? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MCL 1

 

MCL 1 is an anti-apoptotic gene which prevents apoptosis by binding to and neutralizing pro-apoptotic proteins such as BAX and BAK. MCL1 plays a crucial role in resistance to chemotherapy drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PUMA: PUMA (p53 upregulated modulator of apoptosis) is a pro-apoptotic gene that is activated by p53 and plays a role in promoting apoptosis by inhibiting anti-apoptotic BCL-2 family members.

 

Option B. BAD: BAD is another pro-apoptotic protein that promotes apoptosis by binding to and inhibiting anti-apoptotic proteins such as BCL-2 and BCL-XL.

 

Option C. BAK: BAK is a pro-apoptotic protein that, when activated, oligomerizes and disrupts the mitochondrial membrane, leading to cytochrome c release and the activation of caspases, which are crucial for apoptosis.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 7-year-old child brought to OPD with complaints of fever, erythematous rash, and bone pain. X-ray of the skull revealed multiple lytic lesions. Skin biopsy shows prominent nuclear grooves with eosinophils as in the image below. Immunohistochemistry is positive for S100, CD1a. What is the likely diagnosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Langerhans cell histiocytosis

 

The above history along with the histopathological image showing Langerhans cells (image A), CD1a and positive S100 positive, is suggestive of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

 

 

Other option:

 

Option A. Rosai Dorfman disease: Rosai Dorfman disease doesn’t show histiocytes. It presents with painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option B. Kimura disease: Kimura disease presents with painless lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Juvenile Xanthogranuloma: Juvenile Xanthogranuloma shows multinucleated giant cells. It presents with papular lesions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is identified by a combination of clinical symptoms (such as bone pain, fever, and rash), characteristic histopathological features (nuclear grooves, eosinophils), and positive immunohistochemical markers (S100, CD1a). The presence of multiple lytic bone lesions, especially in the skull, is a key diagnostic clue.

questions.text: A young woman, aged 25, presented with hearing impairment that emerged shortly after her initial pregnancy. Provided below is her audiometry findings. What could be the potential diagnosis for this case? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Otosclerosis

 

Hearing loss that developed shortly after the first pregnancy along with Carhart's notch seen in the audiogram is suggestive of otosclerosis.

 

Interpretation of the given audiogram:

 

  • Blue color indicates the left ear.
  • x indicates AC and threshold is >15 dB and hence AC is abnormal. So it indicates conductive deafness.
  • ] indicates BC and threshold is <25dB. A characteristic dip in the BC curve at 2000 Hz called Carhart’s notch is seen.
  • The air-bone gap is a feature of conductive hearing loss.
  • Hence, left-sided otosclerosis is the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Ototoxicity causes SNHL and shows a high-frequency hearing loss in the SNHL curve.

 

Option B: Meniere's disease shows a low-frequency loss in the SNHL curve.

 

 

Option D: Noise-induced hearing loss - PTA shows a characteristic Acoustic dip at 4000 Hz (Boiler’s Notch).

 

 

Educational Objective:

Based on the national immunization schedule, which combination of vaccines would you recommend for this child's initial immunization? [AIIMS MAY 2018]
questions.solution:

choices.text: Pigmented septate hyphae at 90 degrees, Mucormycosis
Right angle branching septate hyphae, Fusarium
Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, dyspnea, palpitations, and tachycardia. The echocardiography revealed vegetation in the septal leaflets. Tissue sections from them reveal the following findings as shown in the image. What is the most likely implicated agent? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Acute angle branching septate hyphae, Aspergillus

 

The given clinical history is suggestive of infective valvulitis with mycotic vegetation. Histologic finding shows an aggregate of fungal hypae with acute angle branching and rare fruiting body (GMS stain) suggestive of aspergillus.

 

Aspergillus – septate, acute branching (40 degrees), and form fruiting bodies. Aspergillus hyphae with the distinct fruiting body can be distinguished from Pseudallescheria boydii and Fusarium spp. by morphology alone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mucor - The fungal forms of mucormycosis are broad, non-septate hyphae. They are wider than Aspergillus species and branch irregularly. The angle of branching is greater than other organisms, and usually approaches 90°.

 

 

Option B. Fusarium - Disseminated fusariosis presents with nodular or necrotic painful skin lesions. It cannot be distinguished from aspergillus by morphology alone and requires culture for identification.

 

Option C. Rhizopus - The main difference between Mucor and Rhizopus is that the Mucor does not have rhizoids and stolons while Rhizopus has both rhizoids and stolons. Further, Mucor has branched sporangiophore while the sporangiophore of Rhizopus is generally unbranched. Also, the Mucor does not have apophyses whereas, the Rhizopus has apophyses in the sporangia.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Aspergillus: Typically seen as septate hyphae with acute angle branching on histological stains such as GMS.
  • Mucor and Rhizopus: Non-septate, broad hyphae with right angle branching, distinguishing them from Aspergillus.
  • Fusarium: Requires culture for definitive identification, although morphologically similar to Aspergillus.

questions.text: Which of the following is NOT a side effect of salbutamol?(AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hypoglycemia

 

Salbutamol is a β2 receptor agonist that is used as a Short Acting Bronchodilator in the relief of acute exacerbations from asthma.

 

It can lead to tachycardia (due to stimulation of the β1 receptors at large doses), Hypokalemia and development of tolerance on long term use due to desensitization of its receptors and in large doses can lead to hyperglycemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hypokalemia: This is a known side effect of salbutamol due to its action on β2 receptors, which increase potassium uptake into cells, resulting in lower serum potassium levels.

 

Option C. Tremors: These are a common side effect of salbutamol due to β2 receptor stimulation in skeletal muscles, leading to muscle tremors.

 

Option D. Tachycardia: Salbutamol, especially at higher doses, can stimulate β1 receptors in the heart, leading to an increased heart rate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Salbutamol can cause hypokalemia, tremors, and tachycardia, but it does not cause hypoglycemia. Instead, it can lead to hyperglycemia due to its effect on glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.

questions.text: Which of the following Immunohistochemistry marker is used in Cyclin D1 negative Mantle cell lymphoma? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) SOX11

 

Mantle cell lymphoma is an uncommon lymphoid neoplasm that makes up about 2.5% of NHL.

 

The tumor cells closely resemble the normal mantle zone B cells that surround germinal centers.

 

Typically, the proliferation consists of a homogeneous population of small lymphocytes with irregular to occasionally deeply clefted (cleaved) nuclear contours.

 

Immunohistochemistry - Mantle cell lymphomas express high levels of cyclin D1. Most tumors are also express CD19, CD20, and moderately high levels of surface Ig (usually IgM and IgD with κ or γ light chain). It is usually CD5+ and CD23-, which helps to distinguish it from CLL/SLL. The IgH genes lack somatic hypermutation, supporting an origin from a naive B cell.

 

Cyclin D1 (CCND1) protein overexpression and/or the t(11;14) (q13;q32) translocation are the pathognomonic hallmarks of mantle cell lymphoma (MCL). SOX11 expression serves as a specific biomarker in cases lacking both t (11;14) and cyclin D1 protein but having a gene expression profile suggestive of MCL. SOX11 expression is associated with bad prognosis in mantle cell lymphoma.

 

  • MYD88: Associated with Waldenström macroglobulinemia.
  • Annexin V: Generally used in apoptosis studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DDs of NHL: -

questions.text: A 5-year-old male child is found to have a unilateral undescended testis on the right side during a routine physical exam. A diagnostic laparoscopy is performed, which reveals blind-ending testicular vessels and vas deferens on the right side. What is the next step in the management of this patient? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Nothing to be done

 

Blind-ending vas deferens and testicular vessels imply anorchism or testicular agenesis. In such cases, no further exploration is required.

 

When diagnostic laparoscopy reveals blind-ending testicular vessels, it indicates the absence or nonviable nature of the testis. In such cases, there is no surgical intervention required because there is no viable testis to locate or bring down. The appropriate management approach is to monitor the patient and provide counseling regarding the absence of the testis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inguinal exploration: Inguinal exploration involves surgical exploration of the inguinal canal to locate and bring down an undescended testis. However, in this case, the diagnostic laparoscopy has already revealed blind-ending testicular vessels on the right side. This finding indicates that the testis is absent or nonviable, and no further surgical exploration is needed.

 

Option B. Abdominal exploration: Abdominal exploration is typically performed when an undescended testis is suspected to be located within the abdominal cavity. However, in this case, the laparoscopy has confirmed the absence of a viable testis on the right side.

 

Option C. Scrotal exploration: Scrotal exploration involves surgical exploration of the scrotum to locate and bring down an undescended testis. However, in this case, the laparoscopy findings have already established the absence of a viable testis on the right side, making scrotal exploration unnecessary.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A unilateral undescended testis refers to a condition in which only one of the testes has not descended into the scrotum, while the other testis has descended normally. This condition is relatively common in male infants and can occur on either the right or left side.

 

Here are some key points about unilateral undescended testis:

 

  1. Incidence: It is one of the most common congenital anomalies in male infants, with the majority of cases involving the left testis.
  2. Diagnosis: Unilateral undescended testis is typically diagnosed during a physical examination, such as a routine well-baby check or pediatric evaluation.
  3. Management: The management of unilateral undescended testis may vary based on the age of the child and the specific circumstances. In many cases, the testis will descend into the scrotum on its own within the first few months of life. If the testis has not descended by the age of 6 months, treatment options may include hormone therapy to stimulate descent or surgical intervention (orchidopexy) to bring the testis down into the scrotum.
  4. Importance of Treatment: The goal of treatment is to ensure that the undescended testis is properly positioned in the scrotum. This is important for several reasons, including the potential impact on fertility and the increased risk of testicular cancer in undescended testes if left untreated.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

  • Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). By inhibiting PCSK-9, evolocumab increases the number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors available on the surface of liver cells, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. It is used for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that works by reducing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. It is used to lower LDL cholesterol levels but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits angiopoietin-like protein 3 (ANGPTL3), which reduces levels of triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, and other lipids. It is used for treating homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor used primarily as an immunosuppressant in transplant patients and in certain types of cancer. It is not related to cholesterol metabolism and is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, evolocumab is the correct answer as it is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to lower LDL cholesterol levels.

questions.text:
Which of the following are true regarding KF ring? (INICET NOV 2020)

 

1. Seen in all patients with neurological involvement

2. Is pathognomonic for Wilson's disease

3. Resolves with desferrioxamine

4. Seen in all patients with hepatic involvement

5. Seen in superior and inferior pole of Descemet's membrane
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1 and 5 only.

 

Statement 1: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is frequently seen in patients with neurological involvement due to Wilson’s disease, but it may not be present in all cases.

 

Statement 5: The Kayser-Fleischer ring is a copper deposit seen at the superior and inferior poles of the corneal Descemet's membrane.

 

Other Options:

 

Statement 2: While the KF ring is highly suggestive of Wilson's disease, it is not solely pathognomonic because it can appear in other chronic cholestatic liver conditions.

 

Statement 3: Desferrioxamine is used for iron chelation and is not effective for copper removal in Wilson's disease. Treatment for copper overload involves agents like penicillamine or trientine.

 

Statement 4: Not all patients with hepatic involvement due to Wilson's disease will have visible KF rings, as their presence correlates more strongly with the duration and severity of copper accumulation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

KF can be seen in disorders causing chronic cholestasis. Seen in ~99% of patients with neuro wilson's, 44-60% with hepatic involvement.

 

Desferioxamine is chelating agent in iron toxicity. 

 

Reference - Harrison/Liver/Wilsons/Chap 344

questions.text: ABCDE rule is seen in: (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Malignant melanoma

 

ABCDE rule applies to malignant melanoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

ABCDE rule for the clinical evaluation of malignant melanoma:

 

A - Asymmetry: One half of the mole does not match the other half.

 

B - Border irregularity: The edges of the mole are irregular, ragged, or blurred.

 

C - Color variation: The mole has different shades of color, such as black, brown, tan, or red.

 

D - Diameter: The mole is larger than 6 millimeters or has grown in size.

 

E - Evolution: The mole has changed in size, shape, or color, or has started to bleed, itch, or crust over.

questions.text: Which drug is contraindicated in a patient with atonic PPH with a history of hypertension? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ergotamine

 

Ergotamine (or methylergometrine) is an ergot alkaloid that is commonly used as a uterotonic agent to manage postpartum hemorrhage (PPH) by promoting uterine contractions. However, it has potent vasoconstrictive properties, which significantly increase vascular resistance and blood pressure.

 

In patients with a history of hypertension, the use of ergotamine is contraindicated because its vasoconstrictive effect can lead to a dangerous rise in blood pressure. This increase in afterload can put additional strain on the heart and may precipitate hypertensive crises or other cardiovascular complications. Therefore, ergotamine is avoided in hypertensive patients, particularly in those with chronic hypertension or other cardiovascular diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Misoprostol: Misoprostol is a prostaglandin E1 analogue that is also used to manage postpartum hemorrhage. It induces uterine contractions but does not have significant vasoconstrictive effects. Therefore, it is not contraindicated in patients with hypertension.

 

Option B. Oxytocin: Oxytocin is another uterotonic agent that works by stimulating uterine contractions. While it can cause mild vasodilation, it does not have the strong vasoconstrictive properties of ergotamine and is generally safe to use in hypertensive patients.

 

Option D. PGF2 alpha: Certain prostaglandins can increase blood pressure and should be used with caution, but they are not as strongly contraindicated as ergotamine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ergotamine is contraindicated in patients with hypertension due to its potent vasoconstrictive effects, which can significantly increase blood pressure and cause cardiovascular complications. This drug should be avoided in hypertensive patients, especially when managing postpartum hemorrhage.

choices.text: Karyotyping of the parents

questions.text: A female comes to Gynecology OPD for pre-conceptual counseling, with 2 prior second trimester abortions. What is the next investigation you will advise? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pelvic sonography

 

Explanation:

 

The most common cause of recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss (RPL) is anatomical abnormalities of the uterus. The initial investigation for anatomical abnormalities is a transvaginal ultrasound (pelvic sonography) as it is non-invasive and provides detailed imaging of the uterine structure.

 

Key Points:

 

  • Recurrent first trimester abortions: Often associated with antiphospholipid antibody syndrome (APLA) or endocrinological causes.
  • Recurrent second trimester abortions: Often associated with anatomical uterine problems.
  • Single spontaneous abortion: Most commonly caused by fetal genetic abnormalities.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Hysterosalpingography: This is not routinely advised for anatomical abnormalities of the uterus. It is more commonly used for evaluating tubal patency and uterine cavity shape but is not the first-line investigation in this scenario.

 

Option C. Endometrial Biopsy: This is advised in women with suspected genital tuberculosis or in women with suspected luteal phase defect. It is not typically indicated for recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss.

 

Option D. Karyotyping of the parents: Chromosomal abnormalities, such as balanced translocations, account for only about 5% of recurrent pregnancy loss (RPL). Therefore, parental karyotyping is not an initial investigation of choice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial investigation for recurrent second trimester pregnancy loss (RPL) is pelvic sonography to evaluate for anatomical abnormalities of the uterus.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 2t6h edition pg 203

questions.text: Which of the following steps are included in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis in a patient with large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis?  (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage

 

MRI is not indicated in patients with acute necrotising pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct steps in the management of acute necrotizing pancreatitis include IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage. Large intra-abdominal fluid accumulation and pancreatic necrosis are complications of acute pancreatitis that require immediate management.

 

Aggressive fluid resuscitation, pain control, and early nutrition are initiated, followed by contrast-enhanced computed tomography to diagnose necrosis. If infected necrosis is suspected, fine-needle aspiration is done, and the aspirate is subjected to Gram staining and culture sensitivity. IV antibiotics are started with carbapenem as the first-choice drug.

 

The step-up approach, which includes percutaneous drainage followed by minimally invasive video-assisted retroperitoneal debridement, is adopted for definitive management. Hence, the correct option is C) IV antibiotics, IV fluids, culture, and assisted drainage.

questions.text: During a medical ethics seminar, Dr. Sharma discussed a series of international declarations that guide medical professionals in upholding ethical principles in various scenarios. These declarations were born out of historical events and societal needs to ensure the welfare of patients and respect human rights. Can you match these declarations with their respective significance? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) I - C, II - D, III - A, IV - B

 

  • Geneva Declaration: It is primarily focused on the physician's dedication to the humanitarian goals of medicine, emphasizing the commitment of the medical profession to human welfare and ethics. This declaration is assigned significance C.
  • Oslo Declaration: It deals with issues surrounding therapeutic abortion, offering guidelines and ethical considerations for medical professionals when abortion is a factor in medical treatment. This declaration is assigned significance D.
  • Tokyo Declaration: Provides guidelines for physicians concerning the ethical treatment of detainees and prisoners, specifically regarding torture and other forms of cruel, inhuman, or degrading treatment. This declaration is assigned significance A.
  • Helsinki Declaration: A cornerstone document that outlines ethical principles for the medical community concerning human experimentation. This declaration provides comprehensive guidelines intended to protect the dignity, rights, safety, and well-being of research subjects. It is assigned significance B.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 33-week multigravida woman presents with epigastric pain, headache, visual symptoms, proteinuria: 3+. The next step of management would be? (INICET NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) MgSO4 IV

 

In the scenario of imminent eclampsia, neuro-prophylaxis with Magnesium Sulfate (MgSO4) is recommended. Imminent eclampsia is characterized by symptoms such as severe headaches, visual disturbances, epigastric pain, and hyperreflexia, indicating that the woman is at high risk of developing seizures (eclampsia). MgSO4 is effective in preventing seizures in women with severe pre-eclampsia and imminent eclampsia, as supported by the Magpie Trial, which is the largest comparative study demonstrating its efficacy.

 

The Magpie Trial (MgSO4 for Prevention of Eclampsia) showed that MgSO4 prophylaxis in women with severe pre-eclampsia effectively prevented the development of eclampsia, making it the standard of care for neuro-prophylaxis in such cases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dexamethasone: Dexamethasone is an antenatal steroid used to enhance fetal lung maturation in pregnancies less than 34+6 weeks. It is administered in doses of 6 mg every 12 hours for a total of four doses. However, it is not used for neuro-prophylaxis in imminent eclampsia.

 

Option B. Betamethasone: Betamethasone, like dexamethasone, is also an antenatal steroid given to enhance fetal lung maturation in pregnancies less than 34+6 weeks. The typical regimen is 12 mg administered 24 hours apart for two doses. It is not used for neuro-prophylaxis in imminent eclampsia.

 

Option D. LSCS: The mode of delivery, whether vaginal or Lower Segment Cesarean Section (LSCS), will depend on the status of the cervical os and other obstetric indications. LSCS is not a prophylactic measure for preventing eclampsia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MgSO4 is recommended for neuro-prophylaxis in women with severe or imminent eclampsia to prevent seizures.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of obstetrics 26th edition pg 1840

choices.text: Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the α -globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the β-globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain
Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the α-globin chain

questions.text: Which Mutation is seen in sickle cell anemia? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation in the β-globin gene (HBB) located on chromosome 11. This mutation results in the substitution of glutamic acid with valine at position 6 of the β-globin chain. The replacement of glutamic acid with a valine causes polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS), leading to red blood cell sickling, increased rigidity, and vaso-occlusive crises. The sickled cells have reduced deformability and tend to aggregate, causing vascular obstruction, hemolysis, and ischemia.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at position 6 of the α -globin chain: Incorrect. The mutation in sickle cell anemia affects the β-globin chain, not the α-globin chain. Additionally, while the amino acid substitution involves valine, it occurs at a specific position in the beta chain.

 

Option B. Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the β-globin chain: Incorrect. While the position (6th) and initial amino acid (glutamic acid) are correct, the substituting amino acid is valine, not leucine. When lysine replaces glutamic acid, it results in hemoglobin C disease.

 

Option D. Substitution of glutamic acid by leucine at position 6 of the α-globin chain: Incorrect. This combines two errors - wrong chain (α instead of β) and wrong substituting amino acid (leucine instead of valine).

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sickle cell anemia is caused by a point mutation resulting in substitution of glutamic acid by valine specifically at position 6 of the β-globin chain.

 

This results in polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin S (HbS), sickling of red blood cells, and complications such as vaso-occlusive crises and hemolysis.

 

 

COMPLICATIONS:

 

  • Vaso-occlusive crisis: most common clinical complication
  • Aplastic crisis: BM overactivity due to compensatory mechanism → parvovirus infection
  • Sequestration crisis: ↑↑↑splenic size leading to hypovolemia
  • Hemolytic crisis- due to infection, splenic macrophage becomes overactive

questions.text: Which of the following hormones is exclusively secreted by adrenal gland but not by the ovaries of females? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) DHEA-S

 

DHEAS is exclusively secreted from the adrenals but not by ovaries because ovaries lack the enzyme dehydroepiandrosterone-sulphotransferase needed to form DHEAS.

 

Adrenal hormones

 

  1. Zona glomerulosa – Aldosterone
  2. Zona fasciculata – glucocorticoids cortisol, corticosterone, as well as small amounts of adrenal androgens and estrogens
  3. The zona reticularis – adrenal androgens dehydroepiandrosterone (DHEA. and androstenedione, as well as small amounts of estrogens and some glucocorticoids

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Progesterone: Incorrect. Progesterone is secreted by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

 

Option B. DHEA: Incorrect. DHEA is secreted by both the adrenal glands and the ovaries.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Incorrect. Estrogen is produced by both the ovaries and the adrenal glands.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DHEA-S (dehydroepiandrosterone sulfate) is exclusively secreted by the adrenal glands and not by the ovaries because the ovaries lack the enzyme necessary to produce DHEA-S.

choices.text: Blurred vision
Steven Johnson Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is not an idiosyncratic reaction of carbamazepine?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Blurred vision

 

Idiosyncrasy is defined as a genetically determined abnormal reactivity to a drug. The drug interacts with some unique feature of the individual, not found in majority of the subjects and produces uncharacteristic reactions. As such the type of the reaction is restricted to individuals with a particular genotype.

 

Idiosyncratic Reactions of Carbamazepine:

 

  • Agranulocytosis: This is a serious idiosyncratic reaction where the drug causes a significant drop in white blood cells, particularly neutrophils, leading to a higher risk of infection.
  • Rash: Skin reactions, including rashes, are common idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine. These can range from mild to severe.
  • Steven Johnson Syndrome (SJS): Although rare, carbamazepine can cause severe skin reactions like SJS, which is a serious condition involving the skin and mucous membranes and requires immediate medical attention.

 

Non-Idiosyncratic Reactions:

 

  • Blurred Vision: This is a common side effect of carbamazepine related to its pharmacological action and dose rather than an idiosyncratic reaction. Blurred vision typically occurs due to the drug's effects on the central nervous system and is not unique to specific individuals based on genetic or other idiosyncratic factors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Agranulocytosis: Agranulocytosis is a potentially life-threatening idiosyncratic reaction associated with carbamazepine, characterized by a significant reduction in granulocytes, a type of white blood cell.

 

Option C. Rash: Skin rashes are common idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine and can vary in severity from mild to severe.

 

Option D. Steven Johnson Syndrome: SJS is a rare but severe idiosyncratic reaction to carbamazepine, involving extensive skin and mucous membrane damage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Blurred vision is not an idiosyncratic reaction of carbamazepine; it is a common dose-related side effect. Idiosyncratic reactions to carbamazepine include agranulocytosis, rash, and Steven Johnson Syndrome, which are unpredictable and occur due to individual genetic predispositions.

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

 

  • Roseola infantum, also known as exanthem subitum or sixth disease, is a common viral illness caused primarily by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) and sometimes by human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7). The disease typically affects young children. It is characterized by a high fever lasting for three to five days, which abruptly resolves and is followed by the appearance of a rash. The rash consists of small, rose-pink or red 2 mm to 5 mm papules and macules. A pale halo can occur around the macules and papules in some cases. The rash usually begins on the trunk and can spread to the neck, extremities, and face. It is typically nonpruritic, blanching, and can persist from one to two days.

 

 

Other Options:

 

In contrast, petechial rashes are small, pinpoint, red or purple spots caused by bleeding into the skin and are associated with the following diseases:

 

Option A. Zika Virus: Zika virus infection can cause a mild, dengue-like illness, which includes symptoms like fever, rash, joint pain, and conjunctivitis. The rash can be maculopapular, and in some cases, petechiae can be observed.

 

 

Option C. Kyasanur Forest Disease: This is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever endemic to South India. It is caused by the Kyasanur Forest disease virus (KFDV) and presents with high fever, headache, severe muscle pain, vomiting, gastrointestinal symptoms, and hemorrhagic manifestations, including petechiae.

 

 

Option D. West Nile Fever: This disease is caused by the West Nile virus, which is transmitted by mosquitoes. Symptoms can range from mild to severe, including fever, headache, body aches, skin rash, swollen lymph nodes, and in severe cases, neurological complications. Petechial rashes can occur in some cases.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in making a diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Cognitive dysfunction

 

Autism Spectrum Disorder (ASD) is diagnosed based on specific criteria that include impairments in social interaction and communication, as well as restrictive and repetitive patterns of behavior. Abnormalities in social communication and socialization, as well as restricted interests and behaviors, are key components of the diagnostic criteria for ASD. However, cognitive dysfunction, while it may be present in some individuals with ASD, is not a primary criterion used to diagnose the disorder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abnormalities in social communication: This statement is correct. Impaired social communication is a core feature of ASD and is part of the diagnostic criteria.

 

Option B. Abnormalities in socialisation: This statement is correct. Difficulties in socialization, which include challenges in social interaction, are also part of the diagnostic criteria for ASD.

 

Option C. Restriction in interests and behaviour: This statement is correct. Restrictive, repetitive patterns of behavior and interests are essential criteria for diagnosing ASD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of Autism Spectrum Disorder includes impairments in social interaction, social communication, and restrictive, repetitive behaviors, but not cognitive dysfunction.

questions.text: You are a researcher aiming to compile and analyze data from various independent studies to enhance the precision of treatment effect estimates for a specific medical condition. Which of the following methodologies is most appropriate for achieving this objective? [INICET NOV 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Meta-analysis

 

Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality:

 

  • 1st preference: Meta-analysis
  • 2nd preference: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs)
  • 3rd preference: Retrospective (Non-concurrent/ Historical) cohort study
  • 4th preference: Prospective cohort study (Concurrent cohort study)
  • 5th preference: Case control study
  • 6th preference: Cross-sectional study
  • 7th preference: Ecological study

 

Meta-analysis

 

  • An objective, systematic review that employs statistical methods to combine and summarize the results of several studies. 
  • A quantitative synthesis of all unbiased evidence, meant for summarizing large volume of data, establishing and determining the magnitude of an effect, and to increase power and precision of studies

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: Observational study design, not suitable for synthesizing data from multiple studies.

 

Option B. Systematic review: Provides a qualitative synthesis of evidence but does not statistically combine results.

 

Option D. RCT (Randomized Controlled Trial): Primary study design, not a method for combining results from multiple studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Meta-analysis is the most effective quantitative approach for synthesizing data from multiple research studies to derive a more precise estimate of the treatment effect.
  • Preference of epidemiological studies for establishing causality - 1st preference is - Meta-analysis

questions.text: Which medication is used to treat an infection caused by the cestode egg of the given organism? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Praziquantel

 

The egg in the image is of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm) and it is treated by praziquantel (5-10 mg/kg once).

 

H. nana egg is colorless, almost transparent, oval, non-bile stained, 30–50 µm (micrometers) in diameter, has polar filaments. When shed in stool they are immediately infective and survive up to 10 days in the external environment, they are embryonated and have a 6-hooked oncospheres inside the shells.

 

Shell consists of two distinct membranes; inner membrane has two small “knobs” or poles from which 4–8 filaments arise and spread.

 

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Ivermectin: Ivermectin is used to treat infections caused by various nematodes and ectoparasites but is not effective against cestodes like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option C. Albendazole: Albendazole is an effective treatment for various helminth infections, including some cestodes, but praziquantel is specifically preferred for Hymenolepis nana.

 

Option D. Diethylcarbamazine: Diethylcarbamazine is used primarily for treating filarial infections, not cestode infections like Hymenolepis nana.

 

Educational Objective

 

Praziquantel is the medication used to treat infections caused by the cestode egg of Hymenolepis nana (dwarf tapeworm). The eggs are colorless, almost transparent, and immediately infective when shed in stool. Praziquantel effectively treats this infection with a single dose of 5-10 mg/kg.

questions.text: Which of the following option is a common size of a Foley catheter used in female patients and patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 14 Fr

 

14 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 14 Fr are commonly used in adult female patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 6 Fr: 6 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 6 Fr are commonly used in pediatric patients or in adults with narrow urethras. They are also used in urodynamic studies to measure bladder pressures.

 

Option C. 16 Fr: 16 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 16 Fr are commonly used in adult male patients. They are also used in patients who have had urethral surgery or who have strictures.

 

Option D. 22 Fr: 22 Fr Foley catheters with a size of 22 Fr are commonly used in patients for suprapubic cystostomy. They are also used in patients who have undergone prostate surgery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

FOLEY’S CATHETER

 

The size in French (12F, 14F, 16F etc.) represents the outer diameter. 1 F = 1/3rd mm.

questions.text: A female working in the matchbox factory presents to the dentist with loose teeth, foul smelling discharge, sinuses and fistulae around mouth and disfigurement of the jaw as shown in the picture below. What is the causative agent for this condition? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Phosphorus  

 

  • The disease mentioned above is phosphorus necrosis of the jaw, commonly called as 'phossy jaw'.
  • It is caused due to exposure to white phosphorus during the manufacture of matches. They were made by dipping the match ends into a mixture containing white phosphorus.
  • Features of phossy jaw- Osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw, with foul-smelling pus discharging multiple sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bromine: Bromine exposure does not cause the described condition.

 

Option B. Antimony: Antimony poisoning can cause various health issues but is not known to cause phossy jaw.

 

Option C. Fluorine: Fluorine toxicity can cause skeletal and dental fluorosis but does not cause the specific symptoms of phossy jaw.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phossy jaw is caused by exposure to white phosphorus, leading to osteomyelitis, necrosis of the jaw, foul-smelling discharge, and significant disfigurement.

questions.text: A patient has a blood glucose level of 200 mg/dL and GFR of 90 ml/min. What is the amount of glucose excreted if the transport maximum of the patient is as shown below? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 30 mg/min

 

The amount of glucose excreted in the above scenario is 30 mg/min.

 

Calculation:

 

Step 1: Total filtered glucose calculated by GFR x Plasma glucose concentration

Here,

 

  • ﻿﻿GFR = 90 ml/min
  • ﻿﻿Plasma glucose concentration = 200 mg/dL= 2 mg/ml (1 dL=100 ml).
  • ﻿﻿Total filtered glucose = 90 ml/min X 2 mg/ml = 180 mg/min.

 

Step 2: Check transport maximum:

Here, as shown in the graph transport maximum is 150 mg/min.

 

Step 3: Calculate the excretion

 

  • Excretion = Total filtered glucose - Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Maximum)
  • As calculated above, total filtered glucose is 180, Transport maximum is 150
  • = 180-150 mg/min = 30 mg/min is the excretion

 

Educational Objective:

 

Total filtered glucose=GFR × Plasma glucose concentration

Excretion=Total filtered glucose−Total reabsorbed glucose (Transport Max.)

questions.text:
Match the snakes with the corresponding images: 

 

Column A:

1. Cobra

2. Viper

3. Python

4. Krait

 

Column B:
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-B, 2-D, 3-A, 4-C


The correct matches between Column A (snakes) and Column B (images) are based on identifying features unique to each snake:

 

  1. Cobra (1 - B): The cobra is identified by its hood and characteristic spectacle mark. In the images, Image B shows a hooded snake with this mark, which is typical of cobras.
  2. Viper (2 - D): Vipers usually have thick bodies and distinctive diamond or blotched patterns. Image D shows a snake with diamond-shaped patterns on its body, which aligns with the viper's appearance.
  3. Python (3 - A): Pythons are generally large and thick-bodied, with irregular circular markings. Image A displays these features, which are characteristic of pythons.
  4. Krait (4 - C): Kraits are slender snakes with alternating bands. Image C shows a snake with white bands on a darker body, which matches the appearance of a krait.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cobra - Hooded with spectacle mark
  • Viper - Diamond-shaped spots
  • Python - Thick and large
  • Krait - White bands on body

b & c are correct
