questions.text:
Which of the following is/are criteria for anaphylaxis? (INICET MAY 2024)

 

  1. Persistent abdominal cramps and vomiting
  2. Hypertension
  3. Urticaria and swollen lips
  4. Respiratory distress
questions.solution:
Ans. C) a, c & d

 

Anaphylaxis is a severe, potentially life-threatening allergic reaction that occurs rapidly and requires immediate medical attention. The diagnostic criteria for anaphylaxis typically involve the acute onset of symptoms affecting multiple organ systems.

 

a. Persistent abdominal cramps and vomiting: These are gastrointestinal symptoms that can be part of anaphylaxis when present with other criteria.

 

c. Urticaria and swollen lips: These are common skin manifestations of anaphylaxis.

 

d. Respiratory distress: Respiratory compromise is a key feature of anaphylaxis.

 

Diagnostic Criteria for Anaphylaxis (Acute onset – within minutes to hours)

 

Involvement of the skin, mucosal tissue + ≥ 1 of the following:

a. Respiratory compromise (e.g., dyspnea, wheeze-bronchospasm, stridor, hypoxemia)

b. Hypotension or associated symptoms

 

≥ 2 of the following:

a. Involvement of the skin mucosal tissue

b. Respiratory compromise

c. Hypotension or associated symptoms

d. Persistent GI symptoms

 

Reduced BP after exposure to known allergen:

A. Infants and children – Low SBP (adjusted to age) or > 30% decrease in SBP

B. Adults – SBP < 90 mmHg or > 30% decrease in SBP

 

Other Option:

 

Option b. Hypertension: Anaphylaxis is typically associated with hypotension, not hypertension. Hypotension is a significant marker for the severity of the reaction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anaphylaxis is a severe allergic reaction that involves multiple organ systems and is characterized by symptoms such as urticaria, swollen lips, respiratory distress, and persistent gastrointestinal symptoms. Hypotension, rather than hypertension, is a critical diagnostic feature. Recognizing these criteria promptly is crucial for the immediate management of anaphylaxis.

questions.text: What is the oxygen carrying capacity of 18-year-old boy with Hb of 14g/dl? (AIIMS May 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 18 mL/dL

 

The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is determined by the haemoglobin (Hb) concentration.

 

The average oxygen carrying capacity of haemoglobin is approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of haemoglobin.

 

Oxygen carrying capacity formula:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = Hb (g/dL) × 1.34 mL/g

 

Substituting the given value:

 

  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 14 g/dL × 1.34 mL/g
  • Oxygen Carrying Capacity = 18.76 mL/dL
  • Therefore, the estimated oxygen carrying capacity for an 18-year-old boy with a haemoglobin concentration of 14 g/dL is approximately 18.76 mL/dL.

 

Educational Objective


The oxygen carrying capacity of blood is approximately 1.34 mL of oxygen per gram of hemoglobin, a crucial metric in assessing the oxygenation potential of blood in clinical settings.

questions.text: The following groups of people must be screened for Ca cervix: (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 25 to 65-year-old females

 

Explanation:

 

According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists (ACOG) and the American Cancer Society (ACS) guidelines (2020), cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years. The guidelines specify the following:

 

ACOG/ACS Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 25.
  • Ages 25 to 65:
    • HPV testing every 5 years (preferred).
    • HPV/Pap co-testing every 5 years (acceptable).
    • Pap test alone every 3 years (acceptable).
  • Age >65: No testing required if a series of previous tests were normal.

 

WHO Guidelines (2020):

 

  • Begin screening at age 30.
  • Primary mode of screening: HPV testing.
  • Frequency: Every 5 to 10 years.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. More than 65 years old: Screening is generally not required for women over 65 if they have had a series of normal screening results.

 

Option B. Less than 25 years old: Screening is not recommended for women under 25 according to ACOG/ACS guidelines.

 

Option D. Teenagers: Screening is not recommended for teenagers as cervical cancer is extremely rare in this age group and the benefits of screening do not outweigh the potential harms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cervical cancer screening is recommended for women aged 25 to 65 years, with various acceptable methods and intervals as specified by the ACOG and ACS guidelines.

 

Ref: ACOG guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, WHO guidelines for screening of cervical cancer, Williams Textbook of gynecology 3rd edition 634, 635.

choices.text: Asphyxia
Vagal inhibition
Laryngospasm
Ventricular fibrillation

questions.text: An Autopsy was conducted on a male with history of drowning. However, no water was found in his lungs, and he was determined to have experienced ‘dry drowning’. What is the cause of death: (INICET NOVEMBER 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Laryngospasm

 

Option C. Laryngospasm : In cases of dry drowning, laryngospasm is a reflex closure of the vocal cords and other airway muscles that occurs when water touches the vocal cords or throat. This spasm can seal the airway, preventing water from entering the lungs but also air, leading to suffocation.

 

Other options

 

Option A. Asphyxia : In typical drowning cases, this happens when water fills the lungs, preventing oxygen from reaching the blood. However, it isn't the direct cause in dry drowning.

 

Option B. Vagal Inhibition : This refers to a sudden stop of the heart due to a reflex action stimulated by extreme stress or shock, particularly cold water impacting the face. It can instantly stop heart activity but is rare.

 

Option D. Ventricular Fibrillation : Ventricular fibrillation is a severe cardiac rhythm disturbance where the heart's electrical activity becomes so chaotic that the heart stops pumping effectively, leading to sudden cardiac death. It can happen due to severe hypoxia from drowning.

 

Educational objective:

 

Dry drowning is characterized by a laryngospasm that prevents water from entering the lungs but leads to death through asphyxia due to a blocked airway.

questions.text: A child with thalassemia is undergoing multiple blood transfusions. What is the best method to detect iron overload? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Liver iron concentration

 

  • Children with thalassemia who undergo multiple blood transfusions are at risk of iron overload, which can cause significant damage to organs such as the liver, heart, and endocrine glands.
  • Monitoring liver iron concentration is the best method to assess iron overload in such children, as it is an indicator of total body iron stores.
  • Liver iron concentration can be measured invasively using a liver biopsy or non-invasively using T2 MRI of the liver. The latter is preferred due to its non-invasiveness.
  • Treatment for iron overload in thalassemia patients typically involves the use of chelation therapy, which helps to remove excess iron from the body. Deferoxamine is typically given through intravenous or subcutaneous infusion, while deferasirox and deferiprone can be given orally.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. MRI T2 myocardium: Quantitative iron overload in the heart is determined using a T2 MRI of the myocardium. However, it can be done sooner if there are symptoms of severe iron overload. It is often performed in children older than 10 years. If the patient's transfusion and chelation histories are unknown, it can still be done.

 

Option C. Serum ferritin: Although serum ferritin is elevated, other inflammatory disorders also cause it to be elevated, making it a less sensitive marker.

 

Option D. NTBI (Non-transferrin-bound iron): Iron in plasma is typically bound to cccc. However, when there is an excess of iron, it is unable to bind to transferrin, which results in the formation of non-transferrin-bound iron. (NTBI). It may serve as a marker for iron excess, however albumin, citrate, and uric acid in the plasma all have an impact. As a result, it cannot be utilized as a tool to quantify iron overload and serve as a guide for designing chelation therapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best method to detect iron overload in a patient receiving repeated blood transfusions is Liver iron concentration.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fixed central airway obstruction


The flow-volume loop shows flattening of both the inspiratory and expiratory limbs, which is characteristic of a fixed central airway obstruction. This pattern suggests an obstruction that affects airflow both during inhalation and exhalation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fixed distal airway obstruction would not typically affect both phases of the loop.

 

Option C. Variable intrathoracic obstruction affects the expiratory phase more.

 

Option D. Variable extrathoracic obstruction affects the inspiratory phase more.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs in a flow-volume loop indicates a fixed central airway obstruction.

questions.text: A gynecologist performs a hysterectomy for endometrial carcinoma. Despite the adequate precaution, the ureter was injured intraoperatively. The gynecologist is not held responsible under? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Medical maloccurence 

 

The gynecologist cannot be held responsible for the above act under medical maloccurence.

 

Medical maloccurence/Inevitable Accident: 

 

  • It is defined as an unfavorable outcome, but not resulting from malpractice.
  • Despite giving best treatment patient may fail to respond properly or may suffer some adverse reactions of the drug leading to temporary or permanent deformities. This is known as a medical maloccurence/inevitable accident.
  • If the doctor can prove this before the court, it will be an absolute defense against malpractice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Novus actus interveniens: This legal term refers to a new intervening act that breaks the chain of causation, leading to a result that might not have been foreseeable. This does not apply here as the injury was directly related to the surgical procedure, not an external unrelated event.

 

Option C. Res ipsa loquitor: Latin for "the thing speaks for itself," this doctrine applies in cases where the injury would not typically occur without negligence. This option would suggest a presumption of negligence because such injuries usually do not occur without a breach in the standard of care. However, the context given indicates precautions were taken, so this is not the best answer.

 

Option D. Physician error: This implies a mistake made by the physician that could lead to legal liability. In this scenario, it was noted that all standard precautions were followed, thus excluding this option as the appropriate answer given that no specific error or negligence was cited.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Medical maloccurence is critical to understand that not all adverse outcomes in medicine result from negligence. Some are inherent risks of medical procedures despite the highest standards of care. Recognizing this helps in managing patient expectations and can protect healthcare providers in cases where complications arise despite proper precautions.

questions.text: 50yr old male presenting with diffuse back pain; Cervical spine Xray shown. What is the likely diagnosis? (AIIMS 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. DISH

 

Explanation:

 

The age more than 50 yrs. and diffuse flowing ossification with no joint fusion and normal iv-disc space favors a diagnosis of DISH.

 

Diffuse idiopathic skeletal hyperostosis (DISH), also known as Forestier disease, is a common condition characterized by bony proliferation of the spine affecting elderly individuals. On imaging, it is typically characterized by the flowing ossification of the anterior longitudinal ligament involving the thoracic spine.

 

There is no involvement of the sacroiliac synovial joints.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ankylosing spondylitis: This condition would typically present with a "bamboo spine" appearance, resulting from fusion across the intervertebral disc spaces and sacroiliac joints, which is not evident in this X-ray.

 

Option C. Klippel-Feil syndrome: This syndrome involves congenital fusion of any two of the cervical vertebrae, which does not match the findings in this X-ray.

 

Option D. Sprengel deformity: This refers to an abnormally high scapula, a condition unrelated to the spinal changes observed in the X-ray.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DISH or Forestier's disease is recognized radiologically by its classic flowing ossification along the spine's anterior longitudinal ligament, sparing joint spaces and disc heights, often seen in individuals older than 50 years without signs of sacroiliac joint involvement.

 

DISH VS   Ankylosing spondylitis

questions.text: All of the following are risk factors of vulval cancer except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vulval hamartoma

 

Vulval cancer has several known risk factors, which include:

 

  • Chronic vulval irritation: Persistent irritation and inflammation can contribute to the development of vulval cancer.
  • Immunosuppressive conditions: Conditions such as pregnancy and HIV infection can compromise the immune system, increasing the risk of vulval cancer.
  • HPV (Human Papillomavirus): Infection with HPV, particularly strains 16 and 18, is a significant risk factor.
  • Smoking: Smoking is a known risk factor for various cancers, including vulval cancer.
  • Condyloma (anogenital warts): Caused by HPV, these warts can lead to changes in vulval cells that may progress to cancer.
  • Sexually transmitted diseases (STDs): History of STDs can increase the risk due to the association with HPV and chronic inflammation.
  • Vulvar dystrophies: Conditions like lichen sclerosus can predispose individuals to vulval cancer.

 

Vulval hamartoma is not a risk factor for vulval cancer. Hamartomas are benign, disorganized clusters of tissue that do not typically transform into malignant tumors.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vulval dystrophy: Vulval dystrophies, such as lichen sclerosus, are risk factors for vulval cancer due to chronic irritation and inflammation.

 

Option C. Smoking: Smoking is a well-documented risk factor for many cancers, including vulval cancer.

 

Option D. Vulval warts: Vulval warts, often caused by HPV, can lead to cellular changes that increase the risk of vulval cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vulval hamartomas are not a risk factor for vulval cancer, while chronic irritation, immunosuppressive conditions, HPV infection, smoking, anogenital warts, STDs, and vulvar dystrophies are known risk factors.

 

Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3rd edition pg 680, Dutta’s textbook of gynecology 6th edition pg 334

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with severe backache for 10 days and urinary incontinence with a history of intervertebral lumbar disc prolapse. There is no H/o fever or weight loss. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Cauda equina syndrome

 

CAUDA EQUINA SYNDROME

 

  • Cauda equina syndrome results from compression (squeezing) of the cauda equina – the sac of nerves and nerve roots at the base and just below the spinal cord in the lumbosacral spinal canal.
  • It is a rare but serious disorder, and a medical emergency.
  • The nerves of the cauda equina provide motor and sensory function to the legs and the bladder.
  • Compression of these nerves can interrupt their function, and the effects can be severe.
  • Causes:
    • Lumbar disc herniation (most common)
    • Trauma
    • Spinal tumor
    • Spinal stenosis
    • Infection
    • Vertebral fractures from osteoporosis
  • Symptoms:
    • Severe low back pain
    • Bladder dysfunction such as urinary retention or incontinence
    • Bowel incontinence
    • Muscle weakness or sensory loss in both legs
    • Loss of motor function in legs
    • Loss or reduction of reflexes
    • Saddle anesthesia (inability to feel anything in the body areas that would sit on a saddle)
  • Investigations:
    • Magnetic resonance (MR) imaging: The best method of imaging the spinal cord, nerve roots, intervertebral discs, and ligaments. Since these scans can detect damage or disease of soft tissue, MRIs are valuable in diagnosing the cause of cauda equina syndrome.
    • Myelogram: Procedure that involves injecting a liquid dye into the spinal column. These X-ray and CT images [usually performed with a computerized tomography (CT) scan] can show pressure on the cauda equina from herniated discs and other conditions.
  • Treatment:
    • Cauda equina syndrome is a potential surgical emergency and may require timely decompression surgery to reduce/remove the pressure on the nerve(s).
    • Undergoing early surgery seems to offer the best chance for improvement of sensory and muscle function as well as bowel and bladder function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pott’s spine. Back pain, usually minimal, is the commonest symptom (1st symptom). Tenderness is the earliest sign. Twist tenderness for anterior elements is more significant as disease involves the vertebral body (paradiscal) anteriorly. Paravertebral muscle spasm resulting in stiffness in the affected region is a constant early finding. The spine is held rigid. When picking an object up from floor, there is flexion at hips and knees and the spine is in extension (Coin test). Earliest sign in patient with neurological deficit is increased deep tendon reflexes or clonus or extensor plantar response (twitching of muscles can be seen even earlier).

 

Option B. Multiple myeloma. Elderly with bone pains, increased ESR and hypercalcemia is multiple myeloma till proved otherwise. Bone pain is the most common complaint for patients with multiple myeloma. In contrast to most bone tumors, other systemic problems, such as weakness, weight loss, anemia, thrombocytopenia, peripheral neuropathy, hypercalcemia, or renal failure, frequently are present at the time of diagnosis of multiple myeloma. Symptoms usually are of short duration because of the aggressive nature of the disease. Pathological fractures are relatively common. The spine is the most common location followed by the ribs and pelvis.

 

Option D. Bone metastasis. The common symptoms include bone pain (frequent symptom), gradual in onset and described as a dull, boring pain that is worse at night. Bone metastases causing nerve root compression can present as radicular pain different from mechanical pain. As the vertebra is the most common site of metastasis, a significant complication includes spinal cord compression, which is an oncologic emergency. Metastatic spinal cord compression occurs either through pathological vertebral collapse or direct epidural extension. Patients may present initially with back pain. Limb weakness is the second most common symptom. Sensory symptoms include paresthesia and numbness at and below the level of cord compression. Autonomic dysfunction, including bowel and bladder incontinence and impotence, is typically a late presentation. In malignancy, hypercalcemia can be multifactorial and confers a poor prognosis overall. Osteolytic bone metastases are associated with 10-30% of the cases of hypercalcemia of malignancy due to enhanced osteoclastic bone resorption. Symptoms include nausea, anorexia, abdominal pain, constipation, and mental status changes. Bone metastases cause bone destruction, increasing the risk for atraumatic fracture.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presenting symptoms and history of the patient are suggestive of cauda equine syndrome caused due to lumbar disc prolapse.

questions.text: Neurotransmitter secreted by the area marked A in the given image is? (INICET May 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dopamine

 

Explanation:

 

The substantia nigra is the region highlighted in the illustration (meaning- dark substance). Dopamine is the neurotransmitter released by this region.

 

A component of the nigrostriatal pathway is the substantia nigra. Parkinson's disease may be caused by the degeneration of dopaminergic neurons.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acetylcholine (ACh):

 

  • Acetylcholine is a neurotransmitter that plays key roles in the peripheral nervous system (PNS) and central nervous system (CNS).
  • In the PNS, ACh is the neurotransmitter released from the axon terminals of motor neurons, making muscles contract. It's also the neurotransmitter in all autonomic ganglia.
  • In the CNS, ACh is involved in a variety of functions, such as attention, arousal, and memory. Loss of cholinergic neurons in the brain, especially in the basal nucleus of Meynert, has been linked with Alzheimer's disease.
  • However, ACh is not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option C. Glutamine:

 

  • It's worth noting that there's a potential mix-up in the options: Glutamine is an amino acid, while "glutamate" is the neurotransmitter.
  • Glutamate is the primary excitatory neurotransmitter in the CNS and plays crucial roles in synaptic plasticity, which is the cellular basis for learning and memory.
  • While glutamate is widespread in the brain, it's not the primary neurotransmitter of the substantia nigra.

 

Option D. Noradrenaline :

 

  • Noradrenaline is both a hormone and a neurotransmitter. It plays roles in attention, focus, and the fight-or-flight response by preparing the body to react to threats.
  • In the CNS, noradrenergic neurons primarily arise from the locus coeruleus in the pons and project to various regions of the brain, influencing attention, arousal, and mood.
  • While noradrenaline plays a role in various brain functions, it's not the neurotransmitter secreted by the substantia nigra.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dopamine:

 

Dopamine is one of the major neurotransmitters in the brain and is involved in several key functions, including mood regulation, reward-seeking behavior, and motor control.

 

The substantia nigra, specifically its pars compacta region, contains dopaminergic neurons that project to the striatum (caudate nucleus and putamen). This pathway is known as the nigrostriatal pathway and is critical for regulating voluntary movement.

 

Degeneration of dopaminergic neurons in the substantia nigra is the primary pathological feature of Parkinson's disease, leading to motor symptoms such as bradykinesia, rigidity, and resting tremor.

questions.text: Mt. Fuji sign is seen in: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Pneumocephalus

 

The Mt. Fuji sign is a radiological sign seen in cases of tension pneumocephalus. Pneumocephalus refers to the presence of air within the cranial cavity. This condition often arises due to trauma, surgical procedures, or infections that introduce air into the intracranial space. The Mt. Fuji sign specifically indicates tension pneumocephalus, where the accumulated air exerts pressure on the brain structures.

 

 

In the Mt. Fuji sign, the frontal lobes of the brain appear to peak sharply, resembling the shape of Mount Fuji. This appearance is due to the air pressure causing the brain to be compressed and elevated at specific points. This sign is crucial for diagnosing tension pneumocephalus because it suggests that the brain is under significant pressure, which can lead to severe complications if not promptly addressed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pneumomediastinum: This condition involves the presence of air in the mediastinum. It is not associated with the Mt. Fuji sign.

 

Option C. Pneumoperitoneum: This condition refers to the presence of air within the peritoneal cavity, typically due to gastrointestinal perforation or surgical procedures. It does not present with the Mt. Fuji sign.

 

Option D. Pneumothorax: This condition involves the presence of air in the pleural cavity, causing lung collapse. It is unrelated to the Mt. Fuji sign seen in pneumocephalus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Mt. Fuji sign is indicative of tension pneumocephalus and is characterized by the peaking of the frontal lobes due to intracranial air pressure.

questions.text: Which of the following features will not be manifested in an infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space?(AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trismus

 

  • Trismus is not a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space.
  • Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vocal cord palsy: This could manifest due to involvement of the cranial nerves (CN IX, X, XI, XII) that are located in the post-styloid compartment. CN X (vagus nerve) palsy particularly can lead to vocal cord paralysis.

 

Option C. Parotid swelling: Swelling in this region may occur as the post-styloid compartment is adjacent to the parotid gland and includes inflammatory processes that might extend into the parotid space.

 

Option D. Horner's syndrome: This syndrome may appear if the sympathetic chain, which runs through the post-styloid compartment, is affected by an infection or its related inflammatory processes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Presentation in a post-styloid abscess:

 

Bulge behind posterior tonsillar pillar.

 

  • Since post styloid compartment contains CN IX, X, XI, XII, their palsies may be seen.
  • Sympathetic chain involvement in this compartment will cause Horner's syndrome.
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • No trismus or minimal trismus
  • General Symptoms - Fever, odynophagia, sore throat, torticollis (due to spasm of prevertebral muscles) and signs of toxemia

 

Diagnosis

 

  • Contrast-enhanced CT scan neck – for extent of a lesion.
  • Magnetic resonance arteriography is useful if thrombosis of the internal jugular vein or aneurysm of the internal carotid artery is suspected.

 

Treatment

 

  • IV antibiotics with aerobic and anaerobic cover
  • Incision and drainage of abscess

questions.text: Reticular fibres are not present in which of the following structures? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Thymus

 

Explanation:

 

Reticular fibres are not present in the thymus. The thymus is a primary lymphoid organ involved in the development and maturation of T lymphocytes (T cells) and does not contain a significant amount of reticular fibers.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lymph Node: Lymph nodes contain reticular fibers within their structure. Reticular fibers in lymph nodes create a network that supports immune cells, such as lymphocytes and macrophages, as they filter and process lymphatic fluid.

 

Option C. Bone Marrow: Reticular fibers are found in the bone marrow. They contribute to the framework of the bone marrow, supporting blood-forming cells and various hematopoietic elements involved in blood cell production.

 

Option D. Spleen: Reticular fibers are present in the spleen. Similar to lymph nodes, the spleen contains reticular fibers that support immune cells and help filter blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Reticular fibres:

 

A form of connective tissue fibre known as reticular fibres, reticular fibres, or reticulin is made of type III collagen released by reticular cells. Crosslinking reticular fibres create a delicate meshwork (reticulin). Soft tissues like the liver, bone marrow, and the tissues and organs of the lymphatic system benefit from the support provided by this network.

 

They differ from type I collagen fibres in that, they are finer and are arranged in the form of a network (reticulum). The fibres appear black in colour on staining with silver impregnation. Due to this affinity to silver salts, they are also known as argentophil fibres.

questions.text: Which can be used as an alternative to breast milk in low birth weight (LBW) child? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Human donor milk

 

  • Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants
  • Low birth weight refers to birth weight less than 2500 grams due to preterm birth or intrauterine growth restriction or both
  • All low birth weight babies should be fed only by breast milk, regardless of the feeding method
  • Expressed breast milk or human donor milk should be given to infants fed by paladai or gastric tube

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Preterm formula & Option C. Term formula: Formula feeds, including term formula feed for infants weighing ≥1500 g at birth and preterm formula feed for very low birth weight infants, can be given when there is a contraindication to breastfeeding or if the mother is sick or human donor milk is not available or toned milk is not available.

 

Option A. Cow milk: Cow milk is not given because it is rich in casein. Casein causes constipation, colicky pain and cow milk protein allergy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Human donor milk is the alternative to breast milk in low birth weight infants

questions.text: Which of the following is a negative acute phase reactants ? (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Albumin

 

Negative acute phase reactants are substances whose serum concentrations decrease in response to systemic inflammation. Albumin is one of the well-recognized negative acute phase reactants. Its levels fall during acute phase response as resources are shifted to produce more critical positive reactants that help in the defense and repair processes.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Haptoglobin: This is a positive acute phase reactant, which increases in response to inflammation.

 

Option C. Ferritin: Also a positive acute phase reactant, often increases in states of inflammation and infection.

 

Option D. C-reactive protein: A classic positive acute phase reactant, it increases dramatically in response to inflammation.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Recommended HPV vaccination schedule for 9- to 14-year-olds according to WHO SAGE guidelines is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1 or 2 doses

 

Recommended Schedule:

 

  • One or Two-Dose Schedule:
    • One dose is considered sufficient for healthy individuals aged 9–14 years.
    • Alternatively, a two-dose schedule may be administered, with the second dose given 6–12 months after the first.

 

Key Considerations:

 

  • Primary Target Group: Girls aged 9–14 years, ideally before the onset of sexual activity.
  • Immunocompromised Individuals: Should receive at least two doses, and where feasible, three doses, regardless of age.
  • Vaccination of Boys: While the primary focus is on girls, vaccinating boys is recommended where feasible and affordable to enhance herd immunity and prevent HPV-related diseases in males. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The WHO SAGE guidelines recommend 1 or 2 doses of HPV vaccine for 9- to 14-year-olds.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient with fever and sore throat was prescribed an antibiotic. Two days later he presents with a maculopapular rash. Which of the following drugs might have caused this? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amoxicillin

 

Out of the options given above, amoxicillin is the only drug which is an antibiotic. It is an amino penicillin. Allergic reactions in the form of skin rashes to Penicillin group of antibiotics are very common, out of which it is the highest with aminopenicillins.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Prednisolone: This is a corticosteroid used in the treatment of asthma to reduce inflammation. Corticosteroids like prednisolone are not typically associated with causing maculopapular rashes. In fact, they are often used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

 

Options B. Salbutamol: Also known as albuterol, this is a bronchodilator used to relieve bronchospasm in conditions like asthma. Salbutamol is not commonly associated with skin rashes like a maculopapular rash.

 

Options C. Fexofenadine: This is an antihistamine used for allergic reactions. It is unlikely to cause a maculopapular rash and is more commonly used to treat such rashes when they are due to allergic reactions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amoxicillin, an aminopenicillin antibiotic, is commonly associated with allergic reactions, including maculopapular rashes. This is a well-known side effect of penicillin antibiotics. Prednisolone, salbutamol, and fexofenadine are less likely to cause such reactions, and in the case of prednisolone and fexofenadine, they are actually used to treat allergic reactions and rashes.

questions.text: Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Hypomenorrhea

 

  • Asherman syndrome is the presence of uterine synechiae, due to the destruction of the endometrium. It can occur because of
    • Trauma to the endometrium following vigorous curettages such as incomplete abortion, postpartum hemorrhage, and elective abortion.
    • Genital tuberculosis
  • C/F: Following a D & C, they present with
    • Hypomenorrhea
    • Secondary amenorrhoea
    • Secondary infertility
  • The diagnosis is made by
    • HSG: Moth eaten appearance/ intra cavitary filling defects
    • Hysteroscopy: Intra uterine adhesions are seen

 

 

  • Management: Hysteroscopic adhesiolysis f/b insertion of an IUCD for 3 months and giving estrogen to build the endometrium

 

 Other Options:

 

Option A. Oligomenorrhea: This refers to infrequent menstruation, which is not the primary symptom of Asherman syndrome. Although it can occur, hypomenorrhea is more characteristic of the condition.

 

Option C. Dysmenorrhea: This means painful menstruation, which is not typically associated with Asherman syndrome.

 

Option D. Menorrhagia: This refers to heavy menstrual bleeding. Asherman syndrome usually leads to hypomenorrhea rather than menorrhagia due to the reduced endometrial surface area.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Asherman syndrome is most commonly associated with hypomenorrhea due to intrauterine adhesions following endometrial trauma.

 

Ref: Page no 459, DC Dutta’s Textbook of gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following drug must always be available for emergency use in labor ward if a patient is on opioid analgesic? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Naloxone

 

Explanation:

 

Naloxone is a narcotic antagonist capable of reversing respiratory depression induced by opioid narcotics. It acts by displacing the narcotic from specific receptors in the central nervous system, thus reversing the effects of the opioid, including respiratory depression. This makes it an essential drug to have on hand in the labor ward when a patient is receiving opioid analgesics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Fentanyl: This is an opioid analgesic used for pain management, not for reversing opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: This is another opioid analgesic and would not be used to counteract the effects of other opioids.

 

Option D. Bupivacaine: This is a local anesthetic used for epidural anesthesia, not an opioid antagonist.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone must always be available in the labor ward for emergency use when a patient is on opioid analgesic to promptly reverse opioid-induced respiratory depression.

 

Ref: Page no 546, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Which of the following proteins of human papilloma virus inactivates Rb gene? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) E7

 

Human Papillomavirus (HPV) is associated with several cancers, including cervical cancer. HPV has two key oncoproteins, E6 and E7, that play a crucial role in the pathogenesis of cancer by inactivating tumor suppressor proteins.

 

E7 protein binds to and inactivates the Rb (Retinoblastoma) gene, which is a crucial tumor suppressor that controls cell cycle progression. By inactivating Rb, E7 disrupts the regulation of the cell cycle, leading to uncontrolled cell proliferation, a hallmark of cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. E6: Targets and degrades p53 but does not inactivate Rb. E6 promotes the degradation of p53, leading to the loss of its tumor suppressor functions, such as apoptosis and DNA repair.

 

Option C. L1: L1 is a major capsid protein of HPV involved in the assembly of the viral particle but does not have a role in inactivating tumor suppressor genes.

 

Option D. L2: L2 is a minor capsid protein involved in viral genome packaging and entry into host cells but does not inactivate tumor suppressor genes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The E7 protein of Human Papillomavirus (HPV) inactivates the Rb gene, leading to disruption of the cell cycle and contributing to the development of cancer.

 

HPV Oncoproteins:

 

 

L1 protein is useful for making vaccine for HPV. (recent INICET ques)

questions.text: Identify the fracture shown in the image below. (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chevallet fracture

 

The image shows a Chevallet fracture pattern. Chevallet fracture is a type of maxillofacial fracture that commonly occurs due to trauma. This type of fracture typically affects the lower jaw (mandible) and is characterized by a specific pattern of breakage along the jawline, often due to a direct impact. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Jarjaway fracture: Also known as J-type fracture, has a different fracture line pattern than what was shown in the image.

 

Option C. C-shaped fracture: Has a curved fracture line resembling the letter C, which is different from the pattern shown in the image.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: An HPE image of the endometrium is shown. The hormone responsible for this is secreted by? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Corpus luteum 

 

The image shows secretory phase endometrium, characterized by tortuous glands rather than straight tubular glands seen in proliferative phase. The secretory changes in the endometrium are caused by progesterone, which is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum during the post-ovulatory (luteal) phase of the menstrual cycle.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Primary follicle: This structure produces estrogen, not progesterone, and is present in the proliferative phase of the menstrual cycle. It does not cause secretory changes in the endometrium.

 

Option C. Granulosa cells: While these cells are important components of follicles and contribute to hormone production, they primarily produce estrogen as part of the developing follicle, not the progesterone responsible for secretory changes.

 

Option D. Theca interna: These cells work with granulosa cells to produce estrogen during the follicular phase. They are not responsible for progesterone production that causes secretory endometrial changes.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Secretory changes in the endometrium are caused by progesterone, which is primarily secreted by the corpus luteum during the luteal phase of the menstrual cycle.

questions.text: Match the following drugs with the targets of their actions: (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A-4, B-3, C-2, D-1
 

  • Trastuzumab is used in HER2/neu positive breast cancers.
  • Infliximab is anti-TNFα monoclonal antibody used in the management of Rheumatoid arthritis.
  • Sirolimus acts by inhibiting the progression of cell cycle from G1 to S phase by blocking mTOR. It is used in the prevention of transplant rejection.
  • Imatinib is a BCR-ABL inhibitor that is used in the treatment of CML.
     

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: If carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, what adverse effect is risked?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hepatotoxicity

 

  • Valproate is metabolized by CYP450 enzymes into a minor metabolite, which is hepatotoxic.
  • Enzyme inducers like carbamazepine phenytoin and Phenobarbital can induce the microsomal enzyme and increase production of this metabolite. This increases the risk of hepatotoxicity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pancreatitis: While valproate is associated with a risk of pancreatitis, the addition of carbamazepine does not specifically increase this risk. Pancreatitis is a rare but serious side effect of valproate alone.

 

Option B. Thrombocytopenia: Thrombocytopenia can be a side effect of valproate, but it is not specifically increased by the addition of carbamazepine. Thrombocytopenia results from bone marrow suppression, which is not directly affected by carbamazepine.

 

Option D. Hyperammonemia: Hyperammonemia is a known side effect of valproate and can lead to encephalopathy. However, carbamazepine does not exacerbate this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When carbamazepine is added to ongoing valproate therapy, there is an increased risk of hepatotoxicity due to the induction of cytochrome P450 enzymes by carbamazepine, leading to increased production of a hepatotoxic metabolite of valproate.

questions.text: All of the following are effective modalities for the prevention of spread of COVID-19 diseases except? [INICET NOV 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) Ivermectin

 

  • Ivermectin has no role in the prevention or treatment of COVID-19 disease.
  • "Studies have shown Ivermectin has no role in the prevention or the treatment of COVID-19 disease." 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mask use: This is an effective preventive measure for COVID-19. N95 masks and triple layer surgical masks as helping in prevention by creating a physical barrier that blocks respiratory droplets which may contain the virus.

 

Option B. Cough etiquette: This is an effective preventive measure. Cough etiquette involves not sneezing or coughing openly but rather doing it in a handkerchief or in the elbow, which prevents the spread of respiratory droplets containing the virus.

 

Option D. Covid vaccine: Vaccines are effective in preventing COVID-19. "COVID vaccines like Covishield, Covaxin prevent COVID and reduce hospitalization and death rates." Vaccines work by training the immune system to recognize and fight the virus before exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ivermectin has no proven role in the prevention or treatment of COVID-19 disease despite early speculation, while mask use, cough etiquette, and COVID-19 vaccines are proven effective preventive measures.

questions.text: Match the following in relation to fingerprint changes: (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-e, 2-c, 3-b, 4-a, 5-d

 

The changes in fingerprints can be associated with various medical conditions and external factors:

 

  1. Incomplete atrophy of ridges - E. Dermatitis:
    • Dermatitis can cause inflammation and swelling, leading to incomplete atrophy of the fingerprint ridges.
  2. Loss of pattern with ridge atrophy - C. Celiac disease:
    • Celiac disease can cause skin changes and atrophy of the fingerprint ridges, leading to the loss of pattern.
  3. Altered ridges - B. Scleroderma:
    • Scleroderma causes hardening and tightening of the skin, which can alter the fingerprint ridges.
  4. Permanent loss of fingerprints - A. Radiation:
    • Exposure to radiation can cause permanent damage to the skin, leading to the permanent loss of fingerprints.
  5. Distance between ridges is changed but pattern is retained - D. Acromegaly:
    • In acromegaly, there is an increase in the growth of bones and tissues, which can change the distance between fingerprint ridges while retaining the overall pattern.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with a history of intractable diarrhea. Based on the histological image shown below which of the following is the most appropriate diagnosis: (AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Multiple myeloma

 

The given clinical history with Russel bodies on histology points to the diagnosis of multiple myeloma. The image shows Russell bodies which are eosinophilic, large, homogeneous immunoglobulin-containing inclusions usually found in a plasma cell undergoing excessive synthesis of immunoglobulins. Russell bodies (INTRACYTOPLASMIC) are distended endoplasmic reticulum.

 

Multiple myeloma usually presents as destructive plasma cell tumors (plasmacytomas) involving the axial skeleton.

 

Malignant plasma cells have a perinuclear clearing due to a prominent Golgi apparatus and an eccentrically placed nucleus. Relatively normal appearing plasma cells, plasmablasts with vesicular nuclear chromatin and a prominent single nucleolus, or bizarre, multinucleated cells may predominate.

 

Other cytologic variants stem from the dysregulated synthesis and secretion of Ig, which often leads to intracellular accumulation of intact or partially degraded protein.

 

Such variants include –

 

  • Flame cells with fiery red cytoplasm

 

 

  • Mott cells with multiple grapelike cytoplasmic droplets and cells containing a variety of other inclusions, including fibrils, crystalline rods, and globules.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphoma: Lymphomas are malignancies of lymphoid cells, and while they can involve plasma cells, the presence of Russell bodies and the clinical history provided is more consistent with multiple myeloma.

 

Option B. Leishmaniasis: Leishmaniasis is a parasitic infection caused by protozoa of the genus Leishmania. It typically does not present with Russell bodies or the plasma cell abnormalities seen in multiple myeloma.

 

Option C. Urate nephropathy: Urate nephropathy involves the deposition of uric acid crystals in the kidneys, leading to kidney damage. This condition does not present with the histological features or clinical history described here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of Russell bodies in plasma cells, along with a clinical history of intractable diarrhea (suggestive of increased risk of infections due to nonfunctional antibodies), strongly suggests a diagnosis of multiple myeloma, a malignancy characterized by the abnormal proliferation of plasma cells.

 

Ref: Robbins pathologic basis of disease, Page No. 1126

choices.text: Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM
Adrenaline 1 mg 1/10000 IV
Atropine 3 mg
Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV

questions.text: The drug of choice in Anaphylactic Shock is? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM

 

Anaphylactic shock is a severe, life-threatening allergic reaction that requires immediate treatment. The first-line treatment for anaphylactic shock is the administration of adrenaline (epinephrine). Adrenaline works by counteracting the severe hypotension, bronchospasm, and edema that occur during anaphylactic reactions.

 

Adrenaline 0.5 mg 1/1000 IM is the recommended dose for the treatment of anaphylaxis. This intramuscular injection provides rapid absorption and action, which is critical in managing the symptoms of anaphylaxis effectively.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Adrenaline 1 mg 1/10000 IV: This dose and concentration of adrenaline are typically used in cardiac arrest scenarios, not for initial treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Option C. Atropine 3 mg: Atropine is used primarily to treat bradycardia (slow heart rate) and is not effective in managing anaphylactic shock.

 

Option D. Adenosine 6 mg followed by 12 mg IV: Adenosine is used to treat certain types of supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) and is not relevant for the treatment of anaphylactic shock.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: NS1 antigen detection
Rapid influenza antigen test

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient presented with a 3-day history of fever, headache, myalgia and retro-orbital pain with no signs of bleeding. On examination, maculopapular rash is seen. Which is the next appropriate step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) NS1 antigen detection

 

The given clinical scenario of a 25-year-old patient presenting with a 3-day history of fever, headache, myalgia, retro-orbital pain with no signs of bleeding and a maculopapular rash on examination is suggestive of dengue fever. The next appropriate step in management is getting an NS1 antigen detection test done.

 

  • Dengue is an acute febrile illness caused by the dengue virus that is transmitted by the Aedes aegypti mosquito.
  • It presents as sudden-onset fever, retroorbital pain, myalgia, arthralgia, and a rash. The initial rash in dengue may appear as flushing erythema of the face in the first 2 days of symptoms. A second rash occurs 3-6 days after the onset of fever and appears maculopapular or morbilliform. Sometimes, lesions may coalesce and appear as 'white islands in a red sea' due to generalized erythema with petechiae and islands of sparing.
  • Before day 5 of illness, during the febrile period, dengue infections may be diagnosed by detection of viral antigens like non-structural viral protein antigen (NS 1) by ELISA or rapid tests. This is considered the mainstay of diagnosis.
  • Virus isolation in cell culture and viral RNA detection by nucleic acid amplification tests (NAAT) can also be done.
  • Serological tests, such as IgM ELISA (option D), are performed after day 5 when dengue viruses and antigens are no longer present in the blood due to the appearance of specific antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Widal test: The Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever caused by Salmonella Typhi and Paratyphi. It is characterized by gradual onset headache, malaise, step ladder pyrexia and gastrointestinal symptoms like abdominal pain with either constipation or diarrhea. They also present with rose spots on the skin during the 2nd to 3rd week, that fade on applying pressure.

 

Option C. Rapid influenza antigen test: The rapid influenza antigen test uses immunofluorescence to demonstrate the influenza viral antigen on the surface of nasopharyngeal cells. The typical clinical disease has a sudden onset of fever, headache, and generalised myalgia. The presence of respiratory symptoms is prominent. It is not associated with retro-orbital pain and maculopapular rash, as given in the above scenario.

 

Option D. IgM ELISA: IgM ELISA is used for detecting dengue-specific antibodies and is generally performed after day 5 of illness. It is not the test of choice in the first 5 days of infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with suspected dengue fever during the first 5 days of illness, NS1 antigen detection is the preferred diagnostic test. It allows for the early detection of dengue infection, before the immune system develops antibodies.

choices.text: Check radial pulse by displacing the cast

questions.text: Earliest way to detect development of compartment syndrome by a nurse in a patient with cast is:(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Decreased response to analgesia

 

COMPARTMENT SYNDROME

 

  • In acute compartment syndromes, increased pressure in a close fascial space causes loss of microcirculation.
  • Most commonly, compartment syndrome involves deep posterior compartment of leg > deep flexor compartment of forearm (commonest in children).
  • It is most commonly seen following fractures of supracondylar humerus and tibia.
  • Most common cause is fractures and dislocations.
  • Other causes are:
    • Crush injury/Burn/Infection/Surgical procedure/Tight circumferential dressing
    • Exercise: Exercise may increase intracompartmental pressure and muscle edema, so it is avoided in cases of acute compartmental syndrome.
  • Clinical Features:
    • The diagnosis of compartment syndrome is based on dramatically increasing pain (out of proportion to injury) after fracture/any injury (1st symptom) not even getting relieved on analgesics.
    • Pain and resistance on passive stretch (Distal most joint of extremity) (1st sign).
    • The pain is unrelieved with opioid analgesia.
    • In compartment syndrome, the order of compression of vascular structures with increase of intracompartmental pressure is: Capillary compression, venous compression, arterial compression.
    • Pulselessness is a late feature and it is not a reliable indicator of compartment syndrome.
    • The presence of pulse does not exclude the diagnosis.
    • In later stages, paresthesia and paralysis ensue due to nerve involvement.
    • Pressures in the deep volar compartment are significantly elevated compared with pressures in other compartments.
    • Deep flexor muscles are involved, particularly flexor digitorum profundus > flexor pollicis longus.
  • Treatment: 
    • The limb should be kept at the level of heart rather than elevated.
    • Removal of all circumferential dressing reduce pressure up to 85%.
    • Fasciotomy is recommended in the presence of clinical signs of compartment syndrome, such as undue pain and a palpable firmness in the forearm.
    • The morbidity caused by fasciotomy is minimal, whereas that caused by an untreated compartment syndrome is much greater.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Check radial pulse by displacing the cast. Pulselessness is the late feature to appear in compartment syndrome. It is not a reliable indicator for the presence of the condition.

 

Option C. Change in colour of fingers. This can occur due to vascular insufficiency but is an uncommon entity.

 

Option D. Change in odor. This is not usually observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The earliest way to detect compartment syndrome in a patient is a decreased response to the analgesics. The patient will complaint of no reduction in the pain symptoms.

questions.text: Match the following weapons with the possible injuries caused by them: (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A-4, B-3, C-1, D-2

 

Mechanism of Injury with the Following Weapons:

 

A. Axe - 4. Chop wound: Axes are heavy and have a sharp edge, causing deep, gaping wounds that are classified as chop wounds.

 

B. RTA (Road Traffic Accident)- 3.Grazed abrasion: In RTAs, the skin may be scraped off, resulting in grazed abrasions due to friction against the road surface.

 

C. Blade- 1. Incised wound: Blades are sharp-edged tools that cause clean, sharp cuts known as incised wounds.

 

D. Lathi - 2. Tram track wound: A lathi, or baton, is a blunt object that can cause parallel linear bruises known as tram track wounds when struck with force.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Mechanism of injury with the following weapons:

questions.text: Neurovascular bundle is absent in which compartment of the leg? (AIIMS May 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior superficial compartment

 

There is no neurovascular bundle in the leg's posterior superficial compartment.

 

The transverse intermuscular septum divides the posterior compartment of the leg into deep and superficial compartments.

 

The gastrocnemius, plantaris, and soles muscles are found in the posterior superficial compartment.

    

 

Neurovascular components in various compartments of leg are as follows:

 

  • Anterior compartment: Anterior tibial artery and Deep fibular/peroneal nerve
  • Posterior deep compartment: Tibial nerve and posterior tibial vessels in the deep plane.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lateral Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment primarily contains the peroneus longus and peroneus brevis (fibularis longus and fibularis brevis in newer nomenclature).
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the superficial fibular (peroneal) nerve. The blood supply comes from branches of the anterior tibial and fibular (peroneal) arteries.

 

Option C. Posterior Deep Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment contains the popliteus, flexor digitorum longus, flexor hallucis longus, and tibialis posterior.
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. The blood supply primarily comes from the posterior tibial artery.

 

Option D. Anterior Compartment:

 

  • Muscles: This compartment houses the tibialis anterior, extensor hallucis longus, extensor digitorum longus, and fibularis (peroneus) tertius.
  • Neurovascular Bundle: These muscles are innervated by the deep fibular (peroneal) nerve. The anterior tibial artery supplies blood to this compartment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior Superficial Compartment has the gastrocnemius, soleus, and plantaris muscles. These muscles are innervated by the tibial nerve. However, this compartment does not have a specific named artery or vein running through it, as the main vessels (the posterior tibial and fibular arteries and their accompanying veins) are located deep in the leg, closer to the bones. Instead, the vascular supply to these muscles comes from branching vessels that penetrate the compartment.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome? (INICET Nov 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Anosmia

 

Kallmann syndrome is a genetic condition characterized by the failure to start or fully complete puberty and an impaired sense of smell (anosmia). It results from an isolated deficiency of gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH), leading to low levels of follicle-stimulating hormone (FSH) and luteinizing hormone (LH), and consequently, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism. Anosmia is the hallmark feature of Kallmann syndrome and helps differentiate it from other causes of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Syndactyly in males: This refers to the fusion of fingers or toes and is not characteristic of Kallmann syndrome.

 

Option C. Precocious puberty in females: This is an early onset of puberty, which is not associated with Kallmann syndrome, as this condition causes delayed or absent puberty.

 

Option D. White forelock: This is a feature of Waardenburg syndrome, not Kallmann syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Anosmia is the most characteristic feature of Kallmann syndrome, which is associated with hypogonadotropic hypogonadism due to isolated GnRH deficiency.

questions.text: The ECG of a pregnant lady having pre-eclampsia is shown below. Her vitals are stable. What is the best step in the management of the condition? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) IV MgSO4

 

The ECG displays characteristics consistent with Torsades de Pointes (Tdp), which is identified by its distinctive polymorphic ventricular tachycardia and a prolonged QT interval. In the setting of pre-eclampsia, magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is not only used for seizure prophylaxis but also effectively treats Torsades de Pointes by stabilizing the cardiac membrane and correcting magnesium deficiency, a common trigger for this arrhythmia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV calcium: Used for treating hyperkalemia or hypocalcemia-induced cardiac toxicity, not directly effective for Torsades de Pointes.

 

Option B. DC Shock: Indicated for hemodynamically unstable patients with Tdp or other life-threatening arrhythmias, which does not apply here as the patient's vitals are stable.

 

Option D. Synchronized cardioversion: Typically used for managing ventricular tachycardia with a pulse or superventricular tachycardia, but not the first-line for Torsades de Pointes in a stable patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a stable pregnant patient displaying Torsades de Pointes, especially in the context of pre-eclampsia, IV magnesium sulfate is the recommended treatment. It helps in both controlling the arrhythmia and providing prophylaxis against eclamptic seizures.

choices.text: Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice

questions.text: Before transferring the patient to the operating theatre, which of the following is necessary to do for a 60-year-old man who has been experiencing abdominal pain for the past six hours, has a BP of 84/50mmHg, RR of 26/min, saturation of 92% with 6 L of oxygen, and has extraluminal air in the abdomen on radiograph? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Administer 2 litres of crystalloid infusion

 

This is the correct option. The patient's low blood pressure (84/50 mmHg) and extraluminal air in the abdomen suggest a possible abdominal catastrophe, such as a perforated viscus. Administering crystalloid fluids is essential to address hypovolemia and improve blood pressure. The goal is to stabilize the patient's hemodynamic status and then perform an emergency laparotomy and repair the perforation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intubate the patient: While intubation may be necessary in some cases of severe respiratory distress or respiratory failure, it is not indicated in this situation.

 

Option B. Insert a central venous catheter as the initial IV access of choice: While establishing intravenous (IV) access is important for administering fluids and medications, inserting a central venous catheter is a more invasive procedure and not the initial step. Peripheral IV access can be established quickly and is usually sufficient for initial resuscitation.

 

Option D. Verify the diagnosis with CECT (Contrast-enhanced computed tomography): While a CT scan may be necessary for confirming the diagnosis and identifying the specific issue, it is not the initial step in managing a patient in this critical condition. Stabilizing the patient's vital signs and addressing potential hypovolemia should come first.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • In the given clinical scenario, volume resuscitation is crucial for maintaining BP as the patient has no history of trauma, indicating a possible bowel perforation.
  • Peripheral large-bore cannula may be used for initial volume resuscitation, and a central venous catheter may be required if vasopressors are planned.
  • Intubation may not be necessary since the patient is maintaining saturation.
  • CT scan may not be necessary as the provisional diagnosis of bowel perforation has already been established, and the patient's vital signs should be considered.

questions.text:
Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia? (INICET MAY 2023)

 

  1. Reduced serum iron level
  2. Reduced transferrin saturation
  3. Increased total iron binding capacity
  4. Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2, 3, 4

 

Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) presents with lowered serum iron levels, decreased transferrin saturation, elevated total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and diminished ferritin levels.

 

1. Reduced Serum Iron

 

  • What it is: This is the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin in the blood.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, the body's iron stores are depleted due to chronic blood loss, poor dietary intake, or malabsorption, so there's less iron available to circulate.
    • Seen in IDA

 

2. Reduced Transferrin Saturation

 

  • What it is: This is the percentage of transferrin that is bound to iron.
  • Transferrin Saturation=Serum Iron​/TIBC×100
  • Why it decreases: Since serum iron is low and TIBC is high, this ratio drops.
    • Seen in IDA

 

3. Increased Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC)

 

  • What it is: This reflects the maximum amount of iron that transferrin can carry.
  • Why it increases: The liver increases transferrin production in an attempt to capture more iron from the gut when body iron is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

4. Reduced Ferritin

 

  • What it is: Ferritin is a protein that stores iron in cells and tissues.
  • Why it decreases: In IDA, body iron stores are depleted, so ferritin levels drop.
  • Important point: Ferritin is also an acute-phase reactant and may be elevated in inflammation, but in pure iron deficiency, it is low.
    • Seen in IDA

 

Summary Table

 

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

C. 1, 2, 3, 4 — all of these changes are classical features of iron deficiency anemia.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by? (NICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Exosome

 

Intercellular communication in eukaryotes is by Exosome.

 

Exosomes are extracellular vesicles generated by all cells and they carry nucleic acids, proteins, lipids, and metabolites. They are mediators of near and long-distance intercellular communication in health and disease and affect various aspects of cell biology. These vesicles are enclosed by a lipid bilayer. They are heterogeneous in size (30-2000 m diameter).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysosome: Lysosomes are organelles involved in degrading and recycling cellular waste, cellular signaling, and energy metabolism. They do not play a direct role in intercellular communication.

 

Option B. Peroxisome: Peroxisomes are involved in lipid metabolism and the detoxification of harmful substances. They are not involved in intercellular communication.

 

Option D. Genome: The genome refers to the complete set of genetic material within an organism. It is not a structure involved in intercellular communication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Exosomes are key players in intercellular communication in eukaryotes, mediating the transfer of various biomolecules between cells and influencing diverse biological processes.

choices.text: Cell wall synthesis inhibition
Cell membrane inhibition
Peptide synthesis inhibition

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of vancomycin? (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cell wall synthesis inhibition

 

Vancomycin binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent used against gram positive agent like MRSA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cell membrane inhibition: This is not the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Drugs like polymyxins target the cell membrane.

 

Option C. Peptide synthesis inhibition: This option is incorrect. Peptide synthesis inhibition is typically the mechanism of action for drugs like tetracyclines and macrolides that interfere with ribosomal function.

 

Option D. 50S ribosome inhibition: This is not the mechanism of action of vancomycin. Drugs like macrolides (e.g., erythromycin), chloramphenicol, and clindamycin inhibit the 50S ribosomal subunit.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, preventing peptidoglycan elongation and cross-linking, leading to cell lysis and death. It is especially effective against gram-positive bacteria like MRSA.

choices.text: Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s
Ceruloplasmin - Hepatolenticular degeneration
High LDH1/LDH2 - Myocardial Infarction
Lipase - Pancreatitis

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes/diagnostic marker is incorrectly paired?(INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Beta Glucocerebrosidase - Von Gierke’s

 

Option A. Defect in Beta glucocerebrosidase is associated with sphingolipid lysosomal storage disorder known as Gaucher’s disease Whereas Von Gierke’s disease is caused due to deficiency of enzyme Glucose-6-phosphatase.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Hepatolenticular degeneration also known as Wilson’s disease is due to defect in ATP7B gene causing defective biliary excretion of copper and accumulation of copper in liver. There is decrease in plasma ceruloplasmin serving as marker.

 

Option C. In normal person, LDH-2 is more than LDH-1 in serum. BUT in myocardial infarction, LDH-1>>LDH-2. This is known as Flipped ratio of LDH in Myocardial Infarction.

 

Option D. Lipase and amylase are increased in plasma in case of Pancreatitis hence they serve as marker enzymes for pancreatitis.

 

Educational Objective

 

Beta-glucocerebrosidase is linked to Gaucher’s disease, not Von Gierke’s disease, which is caused by a deficiency in Glucose-6-phosphatase. Correct pairing of diagnostic markers and associated conditions is crucial for accurate diagnosis.

 

Ref - Harper 31st e/p 64, 167,634

choices.text: It can be left in the eye at the end of surgery.
It damages the corneal epithelium or the endothelium.
SF6 and perfluorocarbon are commonly used viscoelastics.
It is used to maintain the anterior chamber during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding viscoelastic substances used in cataract surgery? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) It is used to maintain the anterior chamber during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion

 

Explanation: 


Viscoelastic substances, also called ophthalmic visco-surgical devices (OVDs), are used to maintain the anterior chamber shape and volume during cataract surgery, particularly during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion. These gel-like materials protect intraocular tissues during surgical procedures and help maintain space in the anterior chamber, making surgical maneuvers safer and easier.

 

Other Options: 


Option A. It can be left in the eye at the end of surgery: This is incorrect. Viscoelastic must be thoroughly removed at the end of surgery as retained viscoelastic can cause post-operative rise in intraocular pressure.

 

Option B. It damages the corneal epithelium or the endothelium: This is incorrect. Rather than causing damage, viscoelastic substances protect the corneal endothelium from surgical trauma and phacoemulsification energy.

 

Option C. SF6 and perfluorocarbon are commonly used viscoelastics: This is incorrect. These are vitreous substitutes used in vitreoretinal surgery, not viscoelastic substances used in cataract surgery.

 

Educational Objective: 


Viscoelastic substances are essential in cataract surgery for maintaining anterior chamber form and protecting intraocular structures, particularly during capsulorhexis and IOL insertion, and must be removed at the end of surgery.

questions.text: Sodium benzoate is given for urea cycle defects for scavenging ammonia. Which amino acid donates amino group to the scavengers? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glycine

 

Sodium benzoate acts as an ammonia scavenger in urea cycle disorders. It works by conjugating with glycine to form hippurate (or hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine. This process provides an alternative pathway for nitrogen excretion when the urea cycle is impaired. The reaction occurs without requiring the urea cycle, thus helping to reduce ammonia levels in patients with urea cycle disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Arginine: Arginine is actually a component of the urea cycle itself and is often supplemented in some urea cycle disorders (except arginase deficiency). It does not directly conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia removal.

 

Option C. Glutamine: Glutamine is involved with another ammonia scavenger, phenyl butyrate, which is converted to phenyl acetate and then conjugates with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine. However, glutamine does not conjugate with sodium benzoate.

 

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is an amino acid that participates in the urea cycle by providing one of the nitrogen atoms for urea formation. It does not conjugate with sodium benzoate for ammonia excretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Urea cycle disorders, sodium benzoate is used as an ammonia scavenger that conjugates specifically with glycine to form hippurate (hippuric acid), which is then excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia? (AIIMS MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin B6

 

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

The sideroblastic anemia comprise a group of disorders of diverse etiology in which the nucleated erythroid precursors in the bone marrow, show characteristic ‘ringed sideroblasts.’

 

SIDEROCYTES are red cells containing granules of non-haem iron. These granules stain ositively with Prussian blue reaction as well as stain with Romanowsky dyes where they are referred to as Pappenheimer bodies.

 

SIDEROBLASTS are nucleated red cells (normoblasts) containing siderotic granules which stain positively with Prussian blue reaction. Depending upon the number, size and distribution of siderotic granules, sideroblasts may be normal or abnormal.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin B12: Important for DNA synthesis and prevention of megaloblastic anemia but not directly involved in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option C. Vitamin B1: Known as thiamine, involved in carbohydrate metabolism, but does not play a role in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron supplementation would not help and could worsen sideroblastic anemia, as the issue lies in the utilization of iron, not in its deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine) is used in the treatment of sideroblastic anemia as it is a cofactor in the heme synthesis pathway and can correct the underlying metabolic defect in certain cases.

questions.text: A child transfers an object from one hand to another. What does it signify? (INICET MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ability to compare objects

 

When a child transfers an object from one hand to another, it signifies their ability to compare objects. This milestone typically occurs around 5.5 to 6 months of age. At this stage, the child is beginning to understand the differences between objects, which is why they are capable of transferring an object between hands. This action demonstrates the child's growing cognitive ability to recognize and compare different objects, an important part of early development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Visual motor coordination: Visual motor coordination refers to the ability to use the eyes and hands together to perform tasks, such as reaching for and grasping objects. While this is important for transferring objects, the key developmental significance of transferring an object from one hand to another lies in the child's ability to compare objects.

 

Option C. Ability to handle small objects: The ability to handle small objects, such as developing a pincer grasp, occurs later, typically around 8 to 9 months of age. This milestone involves more fine motor control and precision, which is different from the broader action of transferring objects between hands.

 

Option D. Voluntary release: Voluntary release refers to the ability to let go of an object intentionally, which is generally seen after the palmar grasp reflex disappears around 4 to 6 months. However, the act of transferring an object from one hand to another is more about the child’s ability to compare objects rather than just releasing them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Transferring an object from one hand to another in a child signifies their developing ability to compare objects, a cognitive milestone typically reached around 5.5 to 6 months of age.

 

Developmental Milestones in 1st Yr of Life

questions.text: SARS CoV-2 diagnosis is done by all except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Southern blotting

 

  • Southern blotting is not a standard method for SARS-CoV-2 diagnosis. It is a technique primarily used for the detection and analysis of DNA fragments, not RNA viruses like SARS-CoV-2. 
  • Diagnosis of SARS-CoV-2 (COVID-19) primarily involves detecting viral RNA or immune response markers. Let's break down the options:

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. RT-PCR (Reverse Transcription PCR) —Used

  • Gold standard for detecting viral RNA.
  • RNA is reverse-transcribed to DNA, then amplified.
  • High sensitivity and specificity.
     

 

Option B. Real-Time PCR —Used

  • Often used in combination with RT (i.e., RT-qPCR).
  • Provides quantitative data and real-time amplification curves.

 

Option C. Southern Blotting —Not used

  • Southern blotting is used to detect DNA, not RNA.
  • It is not suitable for viral RNA detection.

 

Option D. Immunoassays — Used

  • Used for antibody detection (IgM, IgG) or antigen detection.
  • Examples: ELISA, lateral flow assays (like rapid tests).
  • Useful for screening, epidemiological surveillance, and past infection confirmation.
     

 

Educational Objective:
